children.content: Jared Forsyth
Khan Academy
Hi! I'm Jared, and I do mobile & web development at Khan Academy, where we're building a free, world-class education for anyone, anywhere.
Type-safe React with ReasonML
Why?
What?
How?
Why Reason?
What does it look like?
How do I get started?
My goal with this talk is that by the end, you'll be able to answer these three questions.
Outline
Things Reason does that just shine
Reason is a new syntax & toolchain for OCaml.

Now, you might have heard of OCaml from those lists of "5 languages you should learn to make you a better programmer" -- OCaml's been around for 20 years, and has had a ton of work put into it, but its community has remained quite small.

Reason is an attempt to do what Elixir did for Erlang -- invest really heavily in the newcomer experience, make really slick developer tools, use a syntax that will be more accessible to folks coming from mainstream backgrounds, and generally grow the community.
You'll hear me mention bucklescript as well -- it's the compiler that reason uses to target javascript.
Now that brings up another cool thing -- reason is not a single-target language.
You can compile to native desktop (hellooo fast cli tools)
You can compile to native phone (I've shipped a couple of games to the ios & android app stores, compiled to native asm)
To get this started I'm going to need to give y'all a little bit of background.
Reason -> Bucklescript -> JS
Reason -> OCamlOpt -> (mac linux windows) Desktop / iOS / Android
Using the Bucklescript compiler, compilation speed goes from seconds down to miliseconds. By the time you've switched over to your terminal to check, it will have finished compiling.

I have some people one my team that had mostly done mobile native development, and switched to React-Native development, and it just blew them away how much tighter the feedback loop was. Instead of waiting minutes to see their changes, they only wait seconds.
Speaking of bucklescript, the compilation speed is amazing
Why reason?

When introducing something new, I think it's important to pay homage to the things that are already there -- this isn't the first solution for "you're doing web development but you want some more safety". My title is "type-safe react", and you might be thinking "yeah I already have that though". So I'll compare Reason to some existing solutions.
Why not ___?
With flow especially you might ask this question, because both Reason and Flow are coming out of facebook.
I think of it like this -- flow is taking javascript, and making it more like a typed language. Reason is taking a typed language, and making it more like* javascript
[graph]
Talk about the uncanny vally of safety, probably have another visual

Now I'm going to lump Flow and TypeScript together, because they fill the same niche in my mind. They might have somewhat different priorities, and TypeScript has a much better community than flow, but at the end of the day, they're both 80% solutions. It is neither of their goals to be a full type-system -- they're OK with doing a "best effort" job, and prioritising instead compatability with existing javascript to the greatest degree possible.
Now I don't want this to be ragging on flow or typescript -- they've done incredible work on a very hard problem.
...and not Flow or TypeScript?
...and not Elm?
{list}
Why not reason?
Why reason?
What does it look like?
have some cheatsheet looking thing
type x = int
let withNamedArgs = (anonarg, ~namedArg as {destructured, items}, ~optionalArg=?, ~defaultedArg=10, anotheranonarg) => {}
most things are like javascript, but with more structure
can't have objects with arbitrary junk in them. same with arrays etc.
can have named arguments, optional arguments, and default values!
also everything is curried
also you can destructure
The highlights
probably don't have to dive into arrays vs lists
the basic idea is to have it look as much like javascript as is reasonable
Basic syntax
int/string/list(int)/option(string)/{record:string}/A|Sum|Type(int)
Basic types
another screenshot of code, probably
no auto-stringification
prop punning
turns it into a function call, with named arguments
JSX
Hmmm I want to motivate more, like showing places where the javascript would be dangerous
and then "flow says 'no errors', and I don't know why"
OOOOooooooh do the gif "flow gives me an error, and I don't know why"
Some react patterns
maybe also toss in a bit of styles
let's look at a basic component. It just accepts props, it's stateless, so we don't need to define any state type or anything
Basic (stateless) component
add a Js.log() to the button's onClick
Reacting to events
here we're introduced to the reducer!! All state transitions are well-defined, easy to track down.
The organization of redux, with the portability & composability of local state.
A button that, when clicked, increments a counter.
Stateful component
getting fancy now
Render prop
Maybe show iterating over a list of things...
Also child as function, all good stuff
maybe show what you'd do in javascript
"In the talk I gave last year at ReactConf, I talked about how Types make you a better javascript developer.
Do the "loading component" thing
"Make undefined states illegal"
Some react patterns
What does it look like?
How do I get started?
First I'll go through what it looks like adding in some reason to an existing js codebase.
With an existing app

```
$ find .
src/main.js
src/fancy-button.js
src/home-screen.js
.babelrc
package.json
webpack.config.js
```
So here's our setup, much simplified -- we have a webpack config, some existing javascript source files that have react components.

```
$ npm i bs-platform
$ cat > bsconfig.json
{"name": "myapp", "refmt": 3, "sources": ["src"]}
$ ./node_modules/.bin/bsb -make-world -w
... now watching & compiling any reason files
```
Grab bs-platform

```
$ find src
src/OneFile.re
src/OneFile.bs.js
src/main.js
src/fancy-button.js
src/home-screen.js
```
Let's define a component in reason & use it in js

``` // some-file.js const SomeComponent = require("./OneFile.bs.js").myExportedComponent
alert('so awesome')} />
How about using a js-defined react component on the reason side?
With an existing app
You can use create-react-app! which is a quick way to get started.
https://github.com/reasonml-community/reason-scripts
Not much to see here, but it sets up webpack etc for you.
If you're starting fresh
How do I get started?
